results.title: A Dairyland Romance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Keith Harrison and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
Story revolves around the importance of choosing breeding partners that have good breeding themselves and the benefits that this will bring their offspring. It stars two cows with human characteristics (standing on two legs, wearing clothes, speaking english, etc.) being interviewed about their successful partnership together and goes on to give information on correct rearing techniques. Hand-painted animation looks suberb and the deadpan delivery of the main charcaters is very amusing.

Illustrated ‘The End’ and opening titles.

results.title: A Curriculum based on child development
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Elementary School Teacher Education”.
Projects undertaken by typical fourth-grade students are used in explaining the methods employed by an elementary school teacher to adapt the curriculum to the needs of her pupils. Points out that the developmental characteristics of pre-adolescents must be considered in all phases of the curriculum.

results.title: A Curiouse and diverse flora. Pt. 4: change and survival
results.creator_credit: CSIRO and Australian Academy of Science
results.brief_description: Shows how plants have adapted to the range of climatic conditions to be found in Australia, from the dry inland to the tropical rainforests. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: A Curious and diverse flora. Pt. 1: Botany Bay
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, Australian Academy of Science, Nicholas Alexander and Tony Chenn
results.brief_description: This film notes the profusion of previously unknown species of plants discovered by Joseph Banks at Botany Bay, such as banksias, the heath-like epacridaceae, the grass-like restionaceae, boronias, xanthorrhoeas, casuarinas and eucalypts. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: A Curious and diverse flora. Parts 1-5
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, Australian Academy of Science, Nicholas Alexander and Tony Chenn
results.brief_description: Australian flora is shown as first discovered by Europeans in Botany Bay. Other Australian flora is shown from the isolated area of South Western Australia and from Tasmania. The distinctive flora of eucalypt forests and tropical rainforests is also shown. The program is in five parts. Written and presented by Dr. Peter Valder. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: CSIRO, Australian Academy of Science, Nicholas Alexander and Tony Chenn

results.title: A curious and diverse flora. Part 2. An Isolated but related flora
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, Australian Academy of Science, Nicholas Alexander and Tony Chenn
results.brief_description: Examines the flora of the south-west corner of Western Australia, where of the 4000 species to be found, more than three-quarters are endemic to the area. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: A Crutch for all seasons
results.creator_credit: Burt Martin Associates, Burt Martin and Charles Davis
results.brief_description: An examination of the personal dependencies of three young people - for Frank the crutch was liquor, for Billy it was pot, for Max it was hard stuff. Each becomes involved in tragedy and each, at the brink, turns back from his false dependency.
